title: 107_hr2512
content: Authorization of appropriations for United States Customs Service for enhanced activities along the Southwest border. Authorization of appropriations for enhanced border investigative resources on the Southwest border, including funds for salaries, expenses, and equipment for the United States Customs Service. This includes specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2002 and 2003, with additional funding as needed in subsequent years. Authorization of appropriations for enhanced border investigative resources on the Southwest border, including funds for salaries, expenses, and equipment for the United States Customs Service. The allocated amounts for fiscal years 2002 and 2003 are $467,320,000 and $417,832,000 respectively, with additional funding as necessary in subsequent years. For fiscal year 2002, $158,320,000 is designated for acquisition and deployment of narcotics enforcement, cargo processing, and counterterrorism technology along the Southwest border, including mobile truck gamma ray systems and high energy pallet gamma ray systems. The curr_chunk outlines funding allocations for various border security technologies along the Southwest border, including mobile truck gamma ray systems, high energy pallet gamma ray systems, truck x-ray upgrades, nonintrusive inspection equipment operators, technology maintenance, Industry Partnership Programs expansion, canine kennel construction, and replacement of canines. Funding allocations for border security technologies include maintenance of nonintrusive inspection technology, expansion of Industry Partnership Programs, canine kennel construction, replacement of canines, automated targeting systems maintenance, purchase of x-ray vans and tool trucks, refurbishment of existing x-ray vans and tool trucks, contraband detection kits, and remote watch surveillance camera systems. Funding allocations for border security technologies include tool trucks, x-ray vans refurbishment, contraband detection kits, surveillance camera systems, truck license plate reader systems, narcotics particle detectors, land border vehicle targeting systems, under vehicle inspection systems, and outbound passenger facilities. Funding allocations for border security technologies include land border vehicle targeting systems, under vehicle inspection systems, outbound passenger facilities, work station replacements, Customs Automated Operations System lane installations, explosive vapor trace detectors, radiation pager detectors, radiation identification devices, and radiation and explosive detection training. In fiscal years after 2002, $15,832,000 annually is allocated for maintaining and supporting border security equipment and personnel training. In fiscal years after 2002, $15,832,000 annually is allocated for maintaining and supporting border security equipment and personnel training. The Commissioner of Customs may use the funds for technologically superior equipment other than specified in subsection (b). In fiscal years after 2002, $15,832,000 annually is allocated for maintaining and supporting border security equipment and personnel training. The Commissioner of Customs may use the funds for technologically superior equipment other than specified in subsection (b), if it achieves the same results at a cost that is the same or less than the specified equipment, or if it can be obtained at a lower cost than the authorized equipment. In subsection (b), equipment can be replaced with lower-cost alternatives. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate funds within subsection (b) for equipment specified in other paragraphs. $79,000,000 is allocated for peak hours and investigative resource enhancement. In subsection (b), funds can be reallocated for equipment specified in other paragraphs. $79,000,000 in fiscal year 2002 and $172,000,000 in fiscal year 2003 are allocated for peak hours and investigative resource enhancement, including increasing staff at the Southwest border to reduce waiting times and intensify drug enforcement efforts. In order to reduce waiting times at Southwest border entry points to 20 minutes, additional personnel including inspectors, special agents, canine enforcement officers, and general support positions will be hired. $230,000,000 in fiscal year 2002 and $230,000,000 in fiscal year 2003 will be allocated for Customs Service facilities construction and improvement. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, $230,000,000 each year will be allocated for the construction, improvement, and expansion of Customs Service facilities at ports of entry on the Southwest Border. This funding is in addition to any other amounts authorized for the United States Customs Service by law.
